comment: I like the class, and I learned from this class. Professor Musavi helps you to learn how to study the material. He is not hard on students but expects you to do your work.
Not a typical professor. You will see different homework, quizzes, and lectures. But you will appreciate it at the end and feel that you learned something in that class.
He is very knowledgeable about the material and explains stuff way beyond the book, sometimes confusing. Very professional and caring.

I learned a lot, and this is what inspirited me. His tests are tough, but he rounds the exam and quizzes based on the class average. Ask him if you have a question and he response kindly and immediately.

I wish all professors would care about the students as he does. He replies to email immediately or within an hour. He gives you all opportunities to learn the material, but he will not give you a free grade. Material is not easy for this class, but he tries to explain them several time and he does more if you ask him.

Nice and clearly cares about helping students but lectures are incredible difficult to follow and feel unorganized in general. HW and Quizzes are rough because material is not covered clearly enough during lecture or not covered at all. A plus is he's helpful during labs and after class.

I enjoyed the class, and I learned a lot. Professor Musavi is not about the paper or homework; he pushes you to the edge to make you think as much as possible. If you just want to pass, go to class and follow the material. He is accommodating if you ask him questions. But If you want to learn, you have lots of opportunities to learn real-world exa
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: I like his classes. He teaches in a fast past, but he welcomes questions and discussions during the course. If you learn what he is talking about, you mostly get a good grade. Listen and get engaged in the conversation, and you don't need to study much after the class.

I would say that professor Musavi cares for his students and wants everyone in his class to learn useful things rather than learn straight from the book. While sometimes this teaching style is extremely interesting and helpful, it can lead to some confusing moments in class. Overall though his willingness to help when you ask makes up for it.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: He's fairly new to teaching, but he's a fairly solid choice as a professor. He offers a lot of help with the labs and homework. Plus he gives a lot of feedback on the quizzes. Not to mention that he offers a good amount of extra credit opportunities. He uses circuitverse for simulations, but it's user-friendly.

Nice and clearly cares about helping students but lectures are incredible difficult to follow and feel unorganized in general. HW and Quizzes are rough because material is not covered clearly enough during lecture or not covered at all. He is great during labs and much more helpful one on one.

While he is new at teaching, he definitely puts in effort in his lectures and has gotten a lot better. He will goes in depth on the subjects we are learning in lecture to help us understand. He spent a small portion of time on how to use circuitverse (used for HW), but not nearly enough, so you have to teach yourself on how to use the website.

Professor Musavi is new to teaching and it showed a few times during lecture however, he is a solid choice. Willing to answer questions and help his students as best he can. There are homework / quizzes/ labs due regularly, 2 exams, and a final. Some of the quizzes and exams can be tough if he doesn't go over stuff, but I'd take him again.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: He wants his students to succeed, and will graciously answer any questions you have. He doesnt always explain things super clearly, but if you ask him to explain it differently or again he will.

Professor Musavi is a great person, but is fairly new to the teaching aspect. He can be confusing at times but if you don't understand something, just ask. He will break things down until you completely understand. I feel he has improved over the course with his teach ability as well. He grades homework a little harsh and the labs are fairly easy.

Relatively new professor, who clearly cares about the students. Was teaching off of prepared materials and wasn't always familiar with the problems, but that wasn't always bad, as we got to see common pitfalls when working problems. He writes his own problems for quizzes and exams, so you need to pay attention in class, as he covers the material.

He's fairly new to teaching but he's fine when it comes to teaching us the content. He does second guess himself sometimes and has students correct him on certain topics but most of the time he gets the job done. He is very lenient when it comes to grading. Take him but remember, it's a learning experience for the both of you.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: This Professor is still relatively new to teaching but he makes up for it by being more lenient on the grading and will give you opportunities to collect extra credit if you are willing to put in the work. to pass the class the labs are mandatory. but the processor is very responsive during the labs themselves if you are confused on anything

He's a great understanding professor willing to help you understand the material and to earn a better grade, he tries to help inside and outside the class, quick in responding back to emails, he just need more time teaching the class and the system.
The professor is hard to understand some time but he is good overall.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Great guy! Invested in his students and genuinely wants them to learn. I gave his class a higher difficulty rating b/c he was thrown into this class at the beginning of the school year with little to no resources, so he was learning with us. He also grades the HW aggressively. However, he is the most attentive prof I've ever had outside of class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: He is a good professor and cares about his students. Professor Musavi was happy to help me and clear any confusion I had about any topics in EE2501. Some of his examples are wrong but if you ask questions and prove that his answers are wrong, then he will give you credit. The tests are hard and there wasn't enough time to think about each problem
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: EE2501 is a class that is easy to get confused in, but Prof Musavi is always willing to help when you ask for it. He tries to relate the topics to real world matters to help it make sense. This class had labs, and he was more than happy to help you out when you get stuck. Definitely would recommend him to anyone taking the class

He is a good teacher for it being his first year (I believe). Once he settles in a little more, he will be a fantastic teacher. The only thing bad about the class is because he is new, the test didnt have much time. Also its probably just the university or me, but its confusing on what you are suppose turn in for the labs.

I appreciate him because, unlike most of my other professors, he empowers my self-confidence, admits his mistakes, and I learn from him how to think instead of only following directions. I am not saying he is the best, but he made me understand the material. I don't always have to agree with him to get a good grade, and he is always ready to help.

He is a really good guy who is very helpful with one on one help. Not the best during lectures, often doesn't fill up the entire class time. However I took him during his first semester of teaching and was still a worthwhile and quality class.

A solid professor overall. He cares about his students, and he wants everyone to understand the concepts and their application in the real world. Sometimes the details of how to complete the work aren't explained fully during lecture, but he's available and willing to help one-on-one when there's confusion.

He is always more than willing to explain something more than once in different ways to help you understand. The material is confusing, so much so, the teacher can even get mixed up. Gives extra credit If you come to class, so you will do much better than skipping out. He grades fairly.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Professor Musavi is all about motivating his students. He is graduated from Georgia Tech, but he always says, I read the book one day before, and you read the book one day after to give confidence to the students that they can learn the material and give them self-confidence. I learn a lot in his class and specially in the lab.

this man really be trying his best but since he learns everything days before teaching us he can't adequately teachus in a good fashion. Also if 1 thing on thehw is wrong you're probably not making over 50 on the assignment. the only reason the level of difficulty is high is because the lack of teaching, I definitely think if wereDif it would be ez

He does try to explain the material in the lecture the best way he can but when his point does not come across during lecture, he does go the extra mile and try to help you understand the material better when its 1 on 1. He cares about his students and works with you if you ask him and is quick to respond when you email him.

Cons: Some test questions are not easy, and from the material discussed thoroughly before. Pros: Professor Musavi is very responsive to emails. He cares about students, and he gives a lot of extra credit and curves up the exams if the class average is low. Material is not easy, but if you go to the class, you get all the credits.

Professor Musavi knows his stuff, and he cares about his students understanding it, but he's not the most experience when it comes to teaching. He explains things much better 1 on 1, and his homework is graded by accuracy only, not really completion/participation, so keep that in mind.

He's definitely a new professor that is learning the ropes, but that does not mean he's bad. Things that he needs to work on: developing a lecture before coming to class, posting solutions online instead of explaining every graded item in class, and making the requirements for graded items more clear. However, with little effort, students can pass.

The professor tries his best to get his points across, but most of the time you get more confused. He is constantly getting things wrong during lectures and when grading homework/quizzes/tests. Most of the time the info on the tests and quizzes was never covered in-depth, and if it was the prof said 1 thing about it and moved on.

He is a decent professor overall. During some of the lectures, it does seem like he is teaching himself the material. He frequently makes mistakes but he is willing to admit it. I do wish the homework/quizzes weren't as difficult (sometimes they consist of things not discussed in class). Overall, I would take him again.

His lectures seem like he's learning the material along with us, is unclear and frequently makes mistakes during lectures, assignments, quizzes, and tests. Even when disputing a grade, he will refuse to admit he's wrong and you have to fight him to get anything corrected. Hard to understand, inconsistent deadlines and straight-up unhelpful. 0.5/10
He teaches with all of his power, and he expects you to learn it. He gives you all opportunities to learn, and if you understand the subject, you pass the class.
